workflow.name: Categorize support emails with AI and create tasks in Dart
workflow.description:
Automatically turn incoming support emails into categorized, prioritized tasks in Dart‚Äîcomplete with AI-generated summaries, tags, and sender context.

## What It Does

This workflow captures emails from Gmail, uses an AI model to classify them into one of seven categories (e.g., Bug Report, Billing, Feature Request), and creates a structured task in Dart. Each task includes:

- **Title**: The email subject  
- **Tag**: Based on the detected category  
- **Priority**: Set by the AI based on content analysis  
- **Description**: Includes confidence level, rationale, summary, and the cleaned full email body  
- **Comment**: Automatically adds the sender‚Äôs name and email for easy reference

The workflow also parses and cleans the raw HTML email content, ensuring all data is readable and workflow-ready.

## Who's It For

This template is built for support and operations teams using Dart who want to streamline how incoming emails are sorted and turned into actionable tasks. It‚Äôs ideal for organizations managing multiple types of requests and updates from clients, partners, or systems.

## How to Set Up

1. Import the workflow into **n8n**  
2. Connect your **Gmail** and **Dart** accounts
3. Replace the dummy Dartboard ID with your actual board ID  
4. Choose your preferred AI model (results may vary depending on model quality)
5. If your target email address is in a google group, use the **Filter: "Sender"** in the Gmail trigger

## Requirements

- n8n account  
- Connected Gmail and Dart account

## How to Customize the Workflow

- Modify the **category list** to match your team‚Äôs taxonomy  
- Adjust the **AI classification prompt** to fine-tune tagging and prioritization    
- Choose your preferred AI model

nodes.name: Cleaning up full text of email

parameters.text:
=[System instruction]
You are a concise email triage assistant whose sole job is to read a user email and pick the best single category from {Billing, Feature Request, Support Help Request, App Feedback, Bug Report, Task Updates, Unrelated}. Use the definitions and output schema provided below. Output only valid JSON that matches the schema exactly.

Definitions
- Billing: Questions or disputes about charges, invoices, subscriptions, refunds, payment failures, billing address, tax, pricing plan changes, or account credits.
- Feature Request: Suggestions for new features, changes to product behavior, wishlist items, or requests to add/change functionality.
- Support Help Request: User reports of problems, errors, account access issues, setup/installation help, crashes, or anything asking for a fix or step-by-step assistance.
- App Feedback: General feedback about experience, UI/UX suggestions not asking for a new feature, praise, complaints about design/tone/performance that do not request a fix or new functionality.
- Bug Report: Reports describing reproducible software defects, unexpected behavior, incorrect outputs, or developer-facing error traces that require debugging and may need code fixes.
- Task Updates: Notifications or status updates related to tasks, assignments, or workflow progress‚Äîespecially from Dart or similar systems.
- Unrelated: Emails that do not fit any of the above categories, such as promotions, marketing material, job applications, newsletters, or personal messages.

Required JSON output schema (must be followed exactly)
{
  "category": "<one of: Billing|Feature Request|Support Help Request|App Feedback|Bug Report|Task Updates|Unrelated>",
  "confidence": <number between 0.0 and 1.0, strictly in numbers>,
  "rationale": "<one-sentence explanation of why this category was chosen>",
  "summary": "<one-line summary of the user's request>",
  "priority": "<low|medium|high|critical>"
}



Example 1
Email: "I was charged twice this month for my subscription. Please refund the duplicate charge and confirm when it‚Äôs processed."
Category: Billing
Confidence: 0.96
Rationale: "Mentions duplicate charge and explicitly requests a refund."
Summary: "User reports duplicate charge and requests refund confirmation."
Priority: high

Example 2
Email: "It would be great if we could export project timelines as CSV and include custom fields."
Category: Feature Request
Confidence: 0.92
Rationale: "User asks for new export feature and specific fields to include."
Summary: "Request to add CSV export for timelines with custom fields."
Priority: low

Example 3
Email: "App crashes every time I click Save on long tasks; I need help getting my data back."
Category: Support Help Request
Confidence: 0.98
Rationale: "Reports a reproducible crash and asks for help retrieving data."
Summary: "App crashes on Save for long tasks; user needs data recovery help."
Priority: high

Example 4
Email: "Love the new color theme but the contrast on small text feels low; overall experience is much improved."
Category: App Feedback
Confidence: 0.85
Rationale: "Gives UI feedback and praise without requesting changes or fixes."
Summary: "Positive feedback on theme with a note about low contrast on small text."
Priority: low

Example 5
Email: "When running the Code node, I get a stack trace: Error: Code doesn't return items properly at validateRunCodeAllItems ... Please advise."
Category: Bug Report
Confidence: 0.95
Rationale: "Provides a developer-facing stack trace and describes a reproducible failure in node execution."
Summary: "Code node throws validateRunCodeAllItems error with full stack trace."
Priority: high

Example 6
Email: "Task #3421 has been marked complete. Please review the final notes and close the loop."
Category: Task Updates
Confidence: 0.93
Rationale: "Mentions a specific task ID and status update, typical of automated workflow notifications."
Summary: "Task #3421 marked complete; user asked to review and finalize."
Priority: medium

Example 7
Email: "We‚Äôre hiring! Check out our open roles and apply today to join our team."
Category: Unrelated
Confidence: 0.90
Rationale: "Promotional job application email not related to product, support, or user feedback."
Summary: "Marketing email promoting open job roles."
Priority: low

Instructions
- Read the email and map it to exactly one category.

- If the email contains both billing and a technical problem, prioritize Billing if a payment dispute or refund is explicitly requested; otherwise prioritize Support Help Request.

- Confidence Calibration
0.95‚Äì1.00: Explicit intent (e.g., ‚Äúrefund,‚Äù ‚Äúadd feature,‚Äù ‚Äúcrash‚Äù).
0.85‚Äì0.94: Strongly implied intent with supporting context.
0.75‚Äì0.84: Somewhat implied or ambiguous.
<0.75: Weak or uncertain match.

- Priority Rules
critical ‚Äì Use only when the issue completely prevents the user (or all users) from accessing core features, causes total data loss, or exposes a severe security or privacy risk. Typically urgent and business-blocking.
Examples ‚Äì ‚ÄúThe app won‚Äôt load at all for any of our users.‚Äù / ‚ÄúAll my project data disappeared after the update.‚Äù / ‚ÄúSensitive user info is visible to others.‚Äù

high ‚Äì The issue directly affects core functionality, payments, or productivity but does not fully block all access. Includes reproducible crashes, failed payments, or broken workflows with financial or time impact.
Examples ‚Äì ‚ÄúI was charged twice this month for my subscription.‚Äù / ‚ÄúThe app crashes whenever I click Save.‚Äù / ‚ÄúCheckout form gives an error and I can‚Äôt complete my purchase.‚Äù

medium ‚Äì The issue or update affects secondary features, task progress, or non-critical operations. The user can still perform main tasks but with inconvenience or delay. Also applies to workflow notifications and status updates.
Examples ‚Äì ‚ÄúTask #2341 marked complete ‚Äî please review.‚Äù / ‚ÄúThe report export takes longer than usual.‚Äù / ‚ÄúNotifications stopped appearing, but the app still works.‚Äù

low ‚Äì Minor or non-urgent matters that don‚Äôt affect functionality or access. Includes suggestions, praise, design opinions, and promotional or unrelated content.
Examples ‚Äì ‚ÄúLove the new theme, but text contrast is low.‚Äù / ‚ÄúIt would be great if you could add dark mode.‚Äù / ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre hiring! Apply today.‚Äù

- Output only the JSON object and nothing else, matching the schema exactly.

Email: {{ $json.text }}

parameters.content:
## 1. Workflow launch through email capture
Triggered by a new support email via Gmail.

### Email categorization
AI routes each email into one of 7 categories:
- Billing
- Feature Request
- Support Help Request
- App Feedback
- Bug Report
- Task Updates
- Unrelated

### AI metadata assignment
Each email gets:
- **Confidence**: AI certainty score  
- **Priority**: Based on urgency and impact  
- **Rationale**: One-line reason for category  
- **Summary**: One-line digest of the message

### Model selection
Test and use any AI chat model. (Results could vary by model quality)

## 5. Create categorized task in Dart
Convert parsed email data into actionable tasks.

### Task creation includes
- **Title:** Email subject  
- **Tag:** Category (Bug, Billing, Feature, etc.)  
- **Priority:** AI‚Äëassigned based on urgency  
- **Description:** Confidence, rationale, summary, and cleaned email body  

### Sender context as comment
- Add sender name and address as a comment  
- Keeps the task description focused while preserving context  

### Outcome
Each email becomes a structured, actionable Dart task, ready for triage and resolution.

## Support email routing template
This workflows acts as an AI-powered triage assistant. It reads each incoming email, classifies it into one of seven categories, and then automatically creates a task in the selected Dartboard.

### Who's it for
Support and ops teams using Dart to manage diverse inbound requests from clients, partners, or systems.

### How to setup
- Import the workflow into n8n
- [Connect your Dart](https://help.dartai.com/en/articles/12313191-n8n-integration) and Gmail account
- Replace the dummy Dartboard ID with your actual board ID
- Use your preferred AI chat model (Results could vary by model quality)
- If your target email address is in a google group, use the **Filter: "Sender"** in the Gmail trigger

### Customizing the workflow
- You can modify the category list
- Adjust AI classification prompt

## 2. Parsing the AI output
Parse output into a usable format for the next nodes.

### JSON formatting
- **Parse:** AI output into structured JSON  
- **Extract:** Category, Priority, Confidence, Rationale, Summary  
- **Ensure:** Clean, consistent, taggable data

## 3. Full email body cleanup
This node cleans the email body from the Gmail trigger by removing formatting noise and unnecessary content.

### Email cleanup
- **Strip:** HTML tags, inline styles, formatting noise  
- **Convert:** Plain text for easier processing and display

## 4. Retrieve target dartboard
Select the Dartboard in your workspace where new tasks will be created.

### Dartboard targeting
- Locate your Dartboard ID in the workspace  
- Replace the placeholder ID in this node
- Confirms all generated tasks route to the correct board
